We are unlikely to see the Queen strapped to the wing of a plane any time soon but, provided that the current health scare permits, there’s little doubt that she’ll be out and about again being  seen and believed  before too long.

🇬🇧The Queen holds fast to the concept that a monarch must be seen to be believed. 

During the long weeks of lockdown she got a taste of what life would be like in retirement – and it would seem she was unimpressed.

👑Following in the footsteps of her mother, who similarly resisted surrendering to the frailties of old age. 

The Queen Mother relished the bracing fresh air at her remote Castle on the north coast of Scotland. Coughs and colds, she believed, could be blown away by a brisk walk.

👑The Queen is remarkably good at her job, as even Republicans might concede. 

She takes the time to engage with people, genuinely listening to their stories and being interested in their lives. 

When you’re good at your job and you still enjoy it, why give it up?

Age is merely a number, as the Queen noted herself, when gracefully declining an award for  Oldie of the Year  last week. 

 Her Majesty believes you are only as old as you feel 

But there are other reasons why the Queen is not ready to stop working 👇

 No matter what scenario I put up, the most humiliating and frightening things, always the same thing came: kind people will help you… And with that at my side, I managed  says Lumley

Delta outcompeted all other strains at the start of 2021 as it is more infectious and less susceptible to current vaccines.
 
Since then, no other guise of SARS-CoV-2 has managed to gain a toehold in the population.
 
📈AY.4.2 is the first to show sustained growth

🍷Arif also recommends keeping your alcohol consumption to a minimum.

Research shows that heavy drinking can damage many parts of your immune system
Arif recommends looking after your mental health and wellbeing: decades of research show that high levels of stress weaken your body’s ability to fight infections
❓So, what to do to protect yourself against getting Covid for the second, or maybe even third or fourth time?

The good news is that vaccines still seem to offer strong protection from serious illness over time. 

That means that even if you do still catch Covid after being vaccinated, you are less likely to be very ill
Dr Nighat Arif, a GP and ambassador for the UN’s Team Halo vaccine project, says that our surprise at getting ill even after vaccination is often down to a misunderstanding about how vaccines work

💉Although the vaccines offer very good protection against catching Covid, this wanes over time. 

📉An international study found that the Pfizer vaccine was about 84 per cent effective against Covid after six months, compared to around 91 per cent efficacy up till that point

💉Although vaccines offer protection against catching it, even being double vaccinated doesn’t make you bulletproof against coronavirus. 

❓So how can you avoid a Covid reinfection this winter?

⚡What would a meat-free Britain actually look like?

💵Its easy to scoff, as it were, but such products are already making in-roads. 

Greggs, for example, is rolling out a bumper roster of faux meat products this autumn, including a  bacon roll

🥼Riding to the rescue is an ever-expanding army of food technologists. 

🌱Their promise is that we won’t have to give up meat at all. Rather, we will simply replace today’s conventionally produced stuff with either plant- or insect-based alternatives

But there are good reasons, too, why we should continue scoffing the sirloins. 

Meat is, for one thing, fantastically nutritious – a top source of protein and essentials such as zinc, iron and vitamin B12
🔴Meat is responsible for a disproportionate chunk of the greenhouse gas emissions involved in feeding us all, which make up almost 40 per cent of global total according to the latest studies

So what might meat-free Britain look like? Slimmer, possibly. 

⚖️Just take a look at celebrity chef Jamie Oliver, who claimed 28lbs just melted away when he  pushed meat down, pushed veggie up, got more sleep and more movement

You won’t be able to find the 56-page report on the Government’s website anymore. 

It, and its description of a meatless future as a  desirable social norm , have been taken down

A swiftly-deleted research paper this week suggested that a future shunning animal products was desirable.

❓But what would a meat-free Britain actually look like?

🏃The stark impact of Covid 19, and the associated lockdowns, on the nation’s fitness is laid bare in a major new report
🔎Read more on the research into the overlap between over-sleeping and bad health here

💤Two years ago, there were rumours of new government guidelines which were going to suggest we should sleep between seven and nine hours... 

But these never materialised

☁️There is received wisdom about how many hours a person  should  sleep. 

Until this latest study, the oft-quoted  magic number  was eight hours

🗣️ Our study shows that there is a middle-range or sweet spot’ for total sleep time where cognitive performance was stable over time,  says Dr Brendan Lucy, lead author of the study.

❓So what, then, is the sleep  sweet spot ?
⚫️They found that sleeping more than 7.5 hours could increase a person’s likelihood of worsening brain function
Scientists from the Sleep Medicine Centre at Washington University recruited 100 elderly people and monitored their sleep while giving them tests for alertness and cognitive ability

😴But according to a new American study, hitting this  magic number  of eight hours might not be so good for our health – quite the opposite, in fact. 

The study seemed to suggest that sleeping for this long might even hasten the onset of Alzheimer’s disease

⚫️The pandemic only made our sleep patterns worse, with a study last year from the University of Southampton showing that the number of people experiencing insomnia rose from one in six to one in four
⏰For many people, the thought of eight hours’ sleep is a glorious and unattainable dream...

💤What is your sleep sweet spot?

🛏️Many of us can only dream of managing eight hours a night, but new research says that may not be the magic number after all...

The policy is vague, and the language rife with nudges,  Laura writes. 

 We will move from Plan A to Plan B if the NHS comes under unsustainable pressure. It’s under serious pressure every winter so consider yourselves put on notice

The threat of lockdown might be leveraged to justify the introduction of Covid passports.  

 In what is known as a reciprocation nudge, we appear to be given a concession as long as we roll over and accept a less severe option

This week Kwasi Kwarteng said:  I don’t want to reverse back to a situation where we have lockdowns 

 You mightn’t have known there was even a risk of another lockdown. But now the idea has been seeded in your mind, ever so subtly

It was a startling admission, if we needed one, that masks are as much about psychology as they are about preventing infection.  

 They act as a social cue, to use the language of behavioural scientists, nudging us into vigilance

Professor Neil Ferguson said:  Nobody likes having their freedoms curtailed by measures but it’s prudent to be cautious...  

 Wearing masks certainly helps that: it reminds people we’re not completely out of the woods yet

The Government’s strategy becomes ever-more clear. 

 Once nudge is seen, it can’t be unseen. Behavioural scientists were dazzling the public with card tricks. This week, the Government may have overplayed its hand

❓What is nudge theory? 

 It refers to sneaky attempts to push us into their desired course of action, without us ever realising we are being coerced

Controversial nudge theory’ lies at the heart of Westminster’s pandemic response,  writes Laura Dodsworth.

But what is it, and how does it work?

Boris Johnson has committed to the  ambition  of ending the sale of gas boilers in the UK from 2035.

🔎Read more

❓So how soon will we all be getting one? 

Boris Johnson has said builders would be banned from fitting conventional gas boilers in new-build homes by 2025

Sceptics worry that heat pumps will leave them cold during winter.

But one user says he simply left the heat pump switched on  all the time , rather than trying rapidly to warm everything up when arriving home from work

❓Will my home be colder? 

Heat pumps heat the water in your house to a maximum of about 65C – significantly lower than it would reach under a traditional gas boiler

This means they generally take longer to heat your home

Richard Brown, an IT project manager, paid roughly £10,000 last February to replace his gas boiler with a heat pump at his four-bedroom detached house in Derby. 

He says it allows him to save between £300 and £400 a year on fuel costs

❓Will they cost more to run? 

Experts say the average heat pump costs between £6,000 and £18,000.

Ministers claim their £5,000 grants will make the cost of a heat pump comparable to that of a new gas boiler

❓How do they work? 

It works rather like a fridge in reverse, says Will Rivers of the Carbon Trust consultancy. 

 It takes a very large quantity of low-temperature heat, and then compressing it into a smaller volume of high-temperature heat

🔴Heat pumps are the low-carbon alternative being hailed by Boris Johnson as the forefront of Britain’s home heating revolution.

The government will offer grants of £5,000 to help 90,000 households make the switch.

 So I could risk extending, stretching myself out to my full height; being my most confident self

✈️ The first time I went backpacking five years ago, I had never really travelled alone: in the nights before leaving I lay in bed wide-eyed and apprehensive

55 years after the disaster: What now for Aberfan?

One of our top reads of the week 👇

The hospitality sector faces collapse, in part due to our cultural aversion to unsocial hours

Rev Irving Penberthy, 90, is the last surviving minister active in Aberfan in 1966.

He shares his story here
🔴 Read the full long-read from @LauraPowell
It’s about the new generation now. Not the generation, like me, who are coming to the end of our natural lives - what matters now is the youngsters in Aberfan. They’re our future’ says Jeff

For the last five decades those groups continued to meet every week but now, 55 years after the tragedy, both are struggling to stay open due to dwindling numbers, as the generation of adults they first served reach old age.
 
➡️ It is, survivors agree, the end of an era’.

What emerged after the disaster was a handful of social groups, as the tight-knit community drew ever closer:
 
Among them, Aberfan Young Wives, a weekly women’s group, which began in a garden shed in 1967

A young Jeff Edwards was in the same classroom.

 I didn’t know what had happened. The girders from the roof had come down and I was cocooned in an air bubble. I was lucky. There was screaming but it got less - they’d used up the oxygen. 
 
➡️He was the last child recovered alive

Gaynor’s brother, Carl, and sister, Marylyn, in classrooms either side of her, both died that day.
 
 From the side of my eye I saw something black - I got up from my chair and I ran [towards the classroom door]. I never made it  she says

And so, for much of the last 55 years, Aberfan has been something of a time capsule.
 
For people who’ve lived in the village all that time, there’s that constant reminder, seeing the cemetery,’ says Gaynor Madgwick, who survived the disaster at just 8 years old

This was partly due to tradition - generation after generation had lived in the same terraced homes - and partly because bereaved parents wouldn’t, and still won’t, leave their childrens’ resting places

What remains unique about Aberfan is that while the survivors of other large-scale disasters usually disperse home afterwards, or come from a geographically wider area, this community - home to 5,000 in 1966 and 3,500 today - has largely remained in situ

The tribunal report, published in 1967, laid the blame with the National Coal Board, and found that the tragedy was the result of a failure in communications’ after numerous warnings weren’t acted upon.
 
➡️ It was, the inquiry stated, a terrifying tale of bungling ineptitude’

The landslide of Tip Number Seven, which was 500 feet above the coal mining village of Aberfan, engulfed Pantglas Junior School and nearby houses, killing a total of 144 people, among them 109 schoolchildren and 5 teachers

If lateral flows are so accurate, why are so many reporting confusing results?

😷 Professor Peterson says:  Apart from vaccination, lateral flow tests are one of the most powerful tools we have for stopping the infection 

Read the full story

➡️ Additionally, You may develop symptoms but still have a relatively low viral load – so there might not be enough virus for a positive result.

Not blowing your nose properly before the test also increases the chance of a false negative

🦠 It is impossible to tell the difference between a cold and Covid clinically, and it is possible for a swab to miss collecting any virus

It’s mostly likely to happen if someone doesn’t insert the test deeply enough into the nasal cavity

Lateral flow tests respond to a protein on the surface of the virus and can detect signs of infection before any symptoms emerge.

Unlike PCR tests, they don’t require processing in a laboratory and the results are available in around 20 minutes

🧪 However, PCR tests look for fragments of ribonucleic acid left after an infection.

So they’re no good at identifying people who are actually infectious but not yet showing symptoms - who are thought to account for a third of transmissions

❓So what’s the difference between the tests? 

A PCR is considered the gold standard’ diagnostic test, with only 3.5 percent  returning a false negative result

➡️ It’s a confusing picture, but the lead author of the study Professor Irene Petersen believes the fact that lateral flow tests detect infections without symptoms makes them the most effective for reducing infections

🔎 A new peer-reviewed study shows lateral flows detect more than 80 percent  of infections – regardless of whether people have any symptoms.

Yet anecdotally many are finding the tests unreliable

❓If lateral flows are so accurate, why are so many reporting confusing results?

We’ve asked experts how lateral flow tests and PCR tests work - and how to get the most accurate results

⚫️The momentum smart doorbells have built up in their short life, particularly during delivery-fuelled lockdowns, should ensure that they survive a possible legal threat to their existence

More serious crimes are being solved partly with the help of the growing network of what is, in effect, private CCTV. 

The last sighting of Sarah Everard before she was abducted while walking home in south London, was captured on a smart doorbell. 

📸Metropolitan Police/PA

🏠The homeowner might be elsewhere in the house and unwilling or unable to answer. They might be at work. Or they might be in Zanzibar or the Swiss Alps. 

Wherever they are, the delivery man, the meter reader, the Jehovah’s Witness or whoever can be dealt with as necessary

🔊Smart doorbells still make a familiar ding-dong sound but they are also connected to the internet and notify an absent homeowner’s mobile phone when a visitor arrives at their door. 

They can then see and have a conversation with the visitor. 

📸Jamie McCarthy/Getty Image

🏠❓But whether it puts a spoke in the smart doorbell’s inexorable advance – an estimated 16 per cent of homes in the US now have one, while Britain is the second biggest market with thousands being fitted every week – seems less certain
➡️Thought to be the first of its kind in the UK, the judge’s ruling that she had been placed under continuous visual surveillance’ may well set a precedent...

👁‍🗨The smart device allows the owner to watch what is happening outside of their front door on camera. 

🏘️It has this week become the centre of a £100,000 payout after Dr Mary Fairhurst claimed her next door neighbour’s invaded her privacy

I know this not from waking up at the crack of dawn, nor CCTV, but the new method of constant watching: a relative’s Ring doorbell.

✍️Jonathan Margolis

❓How do I know if my runny nose is Covid or a cold?

📈Getting a runny nose caused by Covid is much more likely when rates of the virus are high in the population at large.

📉When rates are lower, it’s more likely to be caused by other conditions, like an allergy or a cold

❓How do I know if my headache is a cold or Covid?

According to Zoe, a Covid headache has particular features that mark it out. They are: 

❌Moderate to severe
❌Last for three to five days 
❌Don’t feel better with painkillers

❓Why are people suffering from the worst cold ever?

Because most of us have been wearing masks, and practising social distancing, for almost two years, we havent had the chance to build up immunity to cough, cold and flu viruses

❓What are the main symptoms of Covid now?

According to the Zoe symptom tracker app, the most common symptom of Covid is a headache.

Other common symptoms include: 
❌Sore throat 
❌Runny nose

… these are also classic features of a common cold

If you feel the urge to panic buy, here’s a better way to react:

🛒Firstly, think back.

Imagine now the sabre-toothed tiger is circling around you in the long grass, and hasn’t pounced yet. You have to live with that 365 days a year. You can never be fully calm. 

🗣️ And that state of anxiety is akin to how we live in society today  says Dr Lim

📅 Dr Lim worries that the trauma of the pandemic has affected all of us, to varying extents, creating a new generation of ever-present circular stressors.

The trouble, he says, is that our cardiovascular systems were simply not built to cope with the pressures of modern life

🔴Dr Boon Lim, a leading cardiologist at Imperial College uses this study to illustrate what he considers a disturbing and potentially deadly impact of coronavirus lockdowns.

 The gnawing impact of constant, low-level stress, circling us like a shiver of sharks in the ocean

📈They found that 24 percent  of patients in the spring 2020 lockdown recorded a high blood pressure, versus 15 percent  in the three months before lockdown.

The increased blood pressure was seen in patients who entered hospital for reasons unconnected to their heart - like a broken leg
🫀 Almost every patient admitted to A&E usually had their blood pressure taken, the researchers wanted to see whether the stress of lockdown was showing up in those readings

🔴In March 2020, doctors at Favaloro Foundation Hospital, in Argentina, were bracing themselves for Covid-19.

📌GTR are the only rail company with a dedicated suicide prevention manager with a focused remit to help prevent suicide and provide support to those who need it.
 
 It’s providing an invaluable service even beyond our industry  writes @lauracDMC

❌Struggles
 
 There are some high-pressure situations which can create really tough and challenging days.
 
 However, hearing stories about our colleagues and passengers who’ve gone above and beyond to save a life is just incredible and so humbling

💼The role
 
 I was determined to do it because my focus is on how many people can be helped by all the work we’re doing to prevent suicide; it’s incredibly important to me

🧒Childhood
 
 My grandmother sadly took her own life when my mum was just four. Back then, there wasn’t much support available to those who experienced the impact that suicide can have
 
 When I found out, I remember being in shock and just feeling so sad for her

For many, the pandemic triggered anxieties and for some, there is now hesitation about life returning to normal’.
 
➡️ For me personally, being able to help people gets me out of bed every morning  write @lauracDMC

⚡️More deaths and tougher restrictions: how the North paid a higher price during pandemic
Among recommendations, the experts have called for more targeted vaccination programmes in the North, an increase in mental health provision and more hospital capacity

According to the report, Northerners also experienced:

❌A larger drop in mental wellbeing 
❌More loneliness
❌Higher rates of antidepressant prescriptions

🗣️ The pandemic has hit us all hard in different ways, but our report shows that people living in the North were much more likely to be hardest hit, both in terms of health and wealth,  Dr Luke Munford, a lecturer of health economics at the University of Manchester, said
The research also showed that Northerners suffered more anxiety and depression
📊The report, by experts at universities across the North, found that care home deaths were also worse, with 5.9 deaths per 1,000 beds compared to 4.7 per 1,000 beds in the Midlands and the South

🔴Northerners were more likely to die in the first year of the pandemic. 

They were also forced to spend 41 more days in severe restrictions compared to the rest of the country

We set out on a sunny June morning, earlier this year, from Lymington Harbour... 

☀️ The bright, clear day must have been a far cry from the dark winter night on which the White Ship sailed

⚓️Despite its historical importance, the White Ship has lain undisturbed at the bottom of the sea for 900 years.

✍️ When Roger Michel, founder of Oxfords Institute for Digital Archaeology, offered me the opportunity to go in search of the White Ship wreck, I didnt hesitate
📢 The ghostly wail of the doomed passengers could be heard on the nearby French shore, where it was mistaken for the sound of rowdy revellers

⚠️The White Ship struck rock lurking underneath Barfleur harbour. 

 The Prince and all of his companions tumbled into the freezing water, ultimately dying of shock, hypothermia and drowning
❌ The oarsmen decided to go as fast as they could in an effort to overtake King Henrys vessel, which had set off several hours earlier - an endeavour any sober man would have deemed ridiculous

🍾Prior to the voyage, the young Prince William got incredibly drunk. 

✍️ With her crew intoxicated, the White Ship was out of control from the moment she cast off from Barfleur

⛵️The White Ship was the fastest vessel of her day, captained by a man called FitzStephen. He had begged King Henry I to honour him with his presence on a trip across the Channel

👑King Henry I declined to board, instead offering the journey to his son, Prince William
✍️ I could not have imagined all those years ago that I would find myself afloat in Barfleur harbour with a team of archaeologists searching for the White Ship wreck,  the Earl writes for @Telegraph

📚According to the Earl, his interest in history was first awakened as a young boy by reading the book Our Island Story. 

The book described  the sinking of the White Ship in the winter of 1120, and the resulting death of Prince William Adelin, heir to the English throne

⚓️👑Earl Spencer has spent his whole life fascinated by the White Ship - whose fate in 1120 shaped the British monarchy. 

So he  couldn’t have been more excited  after finding himself in French waters searching for the ships wreck

But what of those suffering now, waiting for talking therapy appointments?
 
When faced with a pill that promises to cure their pain almost instantly, it’s not hard to see why families will choose the antidepressant route for their child
 
Read more⬇️

Nick Harrop, head of external affairs at children’s mental health charity YoungMinds, says it’s crucial that antidepressants are never seen as a substitute for fast access to talking therapies.
 
Instead, he believes, access to therapy needs to be improved

In my 30 years of practising, I have yet to come across one young person who’s been prescribed antidepressants and this results in a lasting improvement,  Timimi says.
 
 The initial positive response is almost certainly a placebo

Dr Sami Timim, consultant in child and adolescent psychiatry in the NHS:  This has been a terrible year for young people, 
 
❌But, in common with many clinicians who treat children, he is convinced that pills are not the answer

NICE guidelines recommend doctors only consider medication for children with moderate to severe depression, in combination with psychological therapies.
 
Theres concern about the negative effects of antidepressants: side-effects, dependency, withdrawal

Antidepressants are not a first line therapy for children and GPs are not supposed to prescribe them, although increasingly, they do.
 
📝NHS figures reveal that prescriptions for antidepressants given to children aged 5 - 16 had risen by 22 percent  in the past five years

➡️An increasing number of children have been so traumatised by the pandemic that they (or their families, on their behalf) have turned to psychiatric medication: either because of a lack of access to therapy, or because that therapy has not been sufficient

According to the NHSs site, The Centre for Mental Health, an extra 1.5 million children and young people will require mental health support  as a direct impact of the pandemic  during the next 3-5 years.
 
📈Three times higher than the capacity of mental health services
The effect will reverberate through communities long after Covid is consigned to the history books,  says Bernadka Dubicka, chair of the Royal College of Psychiatrists’ Child and Adolescent Faculty
Due to the pandemic – repeated shutdowns, school closures, fear of the virus itself – millions of children have been suffering what could be described as  locked-in trauma

💊Generation Sedated: record numbers of children are on antidepressants.
 
The number of young people taking pills is rising, even though GPs arent supposed to prescribe them.
 
What does science say?

❌However, Lilico warns  there are still challenges ahead with vaccines perhaps waning and our adjusting to a new world in which covid is endemic
❌ But the relentless, exponential growth we saw in the waves of 2020, with more and more hospitalisations and deaths every week for an extended period, is no longer possible
⚡️According to Lilico , specific shocks, for example schools going back this week can take the spread rate back above 1 temporarily...

Reaching the HIT does not mean that case numbers can never rise again.

 But it does mean that case numbers cannot, given that set of behaviours and that time of year, rise again on a consistent, sustainable, exponential basis 

✍️@andrew_lilico
We have reached what is called the herd immunity threshold’ (HIT) – the collective percentage immunity, across the whole population, at which the virus can no longer sustainably spread,  he says

The first thing to emphasise is that this fall is not the result of some special temporary factor 

According to Lilico, the collective immunity we now have means that the virus cannot find enough susceptible people to infect for its rate of spread to accelerate

📉 Coronavirus cases are now falling in England, and have been doing so solidly for over a week. 

 Barring some unforeseen calamity, this marks the de facto end of the English epidemic 

✍️@andrew_lilico

If you have symptoms that cannot be explained and are persistent, you should urgently make an appointment with your GP,  Kate Keightley from Blood Cancer UK said.
 
Read more⬇️

Symptoms vary between patients.
 
Some of the most common signs of blood cancer are:
❌Persistent and unexplained tiredness
❌Unexplained weight loss
❌Unexplained bruising and/or bleeding
❌Persistent infections
❌Bone and joint pain
❌Breathlessness

FORTY THOUSAND
 
Around 40,000 blood cancer diagnoses and 15,000 deaths occur every year in the UK.
 
Estimates suggest that 250,000 people are currently living with the disease
⁉️How many blood cancer diagnoses occur every year in the UK?

📈56 PERCENT
 
Of the 2,000 adults surveyed 56 percent  could not name a common sign of blood cancer, up from 52 percent  in 2018.
 
Blood Cancer UK said it was unclear why this number had risen and called it  really concerning
⁉️What percentage of the 2,000 adults surveyed could not name a common sign of blood cancer?

🦠CORONAVIRUS
 
 During the height of the pandemic, we saw far fewer people being diagnosed with blood cancer, and one of the reasons for this could be that some of the symptoms of blood cancer are easily mistaken for Covid,  said Kate Keightley, from Blood Cancer UK
⁉️What illness are scientists concerned key symptoms of blood cancer could be confused with?

➡️ONE PERCENT
 
The poll, by Blood Cancer UK, found that just 1 percent  of adults were able to correctly identify fever and 3 percent  identified breathlessness as signs of the disease
⁉️What percentage of adults were able to correctly identify fever as a signs of the blood cancer?

🔴Shocking research has come to light on just how little adults in the UK know about the symptoms of blood cancer...
 
And its leaving many with cancer left undiagnosed.

⚡️ I was shaking and crying’ – why I ditched my high-flying City law career
🔎Read more on how Laura’s decision to quit her high-flying job changed her life for the better here 👇

After the pandemic hit, Laura knew she didn’t want to carry on.

❌ And so I made what now feels like the best decision ever: after 21 years of striving and only just surviving, I ditched my City career

Looking back, I don’t know how we got through it. 

🍼 What I do know is that I found myself wishing away the baby phase and longing for the time when my child would sleep through the night

I returned to work when my son was just a few months old, juggling the long work hours with caring for a baby. 

💰 For three months, I worked until 3am almost every night on a billion-dollar transaction

The workload was relentless, with deal after deal after deal. 

🤰 Even at eight months pregnant I had to stay at the office all night and into the following day to get one signed 

✍️Laura Brunnen
❓Do you find it hard to strike a work-life balance?

I was thrilled to win a training contract at a prestigious Magic Circle firm in the City, and started in 2000, when I was 23.

 It soon started to take over my life

I grew up in a working class Hertfordshire family and was the first to attend university. 

 I didn’t know what I wanted to do after graduating, but when one of my friends signed up for law school, it seemed as sensible an idea as any 

✍️Laura Brunnen

🗣️ I was shaking and crying  

💼A former City lawyer talks about why she ditched her high-flying career after her job took over her life

⚡️ Some forms of common cold offer Covid protection, says new research

🗣️Current vaccines  are reducing infection rate, but not as much as we ideally would like 

Read the full story here 👇

💉While the current vaccines do reduce infection rates, Prof Maini says targeting and generating T-cells will add another layer of protection.

 What we’re saying is let’s specifically target both the spike, which we’re already doing, and this new area

🤒That doesn’t mean the common cold will automatically boost your immunity.

 Only 10 percent  of what we recognise as common colds are actually caused by coronaviruses,  says Prof Maini.

 Just because you had a common cold doesn’t mean you’ve actually had a coronavirus

Prof Maini explained:  We think the way they’re doing that is because they’ve already been primed by a previous infection. 

👉 So they’re in a state where they can kick into action much quicker than normal

People have always thought of T-cells as being a secondary line of defence that comes later on. 

🔬 But what’s interesting is our work and several other studies on Covid, are showing that they can actually act very, very early on

💉 Antibodies are very good at preventing infection from getting into the cells,  Prof Maini adds.

 But, if some of the virus gets into your cells, the T-cells can do a great job at clearing those infected cells

🗣️ We think people (who resisted the infection) already had some T-cells from previous infections,  says Professor Mala Maini.

 And that allowed them to mount a very quick response that could abort the infection

The study, by UCL monitored a group of 750 healthcare workers in the first wave of the pandemic.

➡️They found that 58 never tested positive, despite being in a high risk environment

🦠New research has revealed that some forms of the common cold can offer protection against Covid-19.

This is thanks to residual infection-fighting T-cells that prevent the virus from taking hold

Days later I sat in the café two streets from where John had lived, as his friends arrived one by one. The weight of human history that they carried into the room with them was overwhelming

Eventually, my producer came across a death certificate for John Eaddie, born on April 19, 1932 in Saltburn, Yorkshire 

The handwritten cause of death: pneumocystis pneumonia. 

➡️ This was the only match.

By pulling together three vital pieces of information – the patient’s age, the hospital he died at and his suggested cause of death – we were able to begin trawling through thousands of death records to try and find him

Our starting point was an entry in The Lancet from December 1981, now widely agreed to be the first record of a patient to die of AIDS in the UK 

➡️ The doctors coldly noted that  he was homosexual  and had  travelled to the United States

📅 Paul Brand has spent three months tracing his story for an ITV documentary, which will mark four decades of the AIDS epidemic in the UK.

🔴For all this time, the 49-year-old has remained a medical mystery, referred to simply as Patient Zero’.

 His name was John Eaddie and he is believed to be the first person to have died with AIDS in Britain

❓What should we do in the morning?

 Morning light is essential  says Meadows

So switch on a bright light when you get up

🌞A 10-minute walk at 10am will improve our mental health and our sleep no end

😴So what can we do to get the best quality sleep? 

 First and foremost you need to keep to regular sleep/wake times 

📱 In the last hour before going to bed, do some simple things like switching off the telly and all devices like laptops and phones

📈 We also know that sleep plays a fundamental role in insulin regulation – that’s the hormone that controls our blood sugar – so lack of sleep can lead to changes in insulin sensitivity  says Guy Meadows

🧠The purpose of sleep is to activate your parasympathetic nervous system leading to relaxation, growth and repair, recovery and immunity.

But when you are sleep deprived you’re pushed into a state of sympathetic dominance. 

➡️So basically, fight or flight.

💤 In order to stay healthy, we need to sleep in sync with our natural circadian rhythms  says Guy Meadows, Clinical Director of the Sleep School

 There are lots of links between sleep disturbance and heart disease...disturbed sleep increases your blood pressure
⏰The study found that those who dozed off between 10pm and 10.59pm had a lower risk of cardiovascular disease and stroke than those who dozed off earlier or later

How to stop microplastics getting into your body

Dr Donnais recommendations include:

1⃣ Avoiding reheating takeaway food in plastic boxes
2⃣ Using a glass water bottle instead of a plastic one
3⃣ Avoiding using cling film on hot food
4⃣ Using metal or glass coffee cups

So, how do we stop microplastics getting into our bodies?

♻️Dr Donnai is sure that everyone can reduce their exposure with a few easy tweaks
It is not yet known what a healthy level of microplastics might look like, but Dr Sabine Donnai, CEO of the Viavi clinic, is adamant that many people in the West are over the threshold

❌Although research is in its infancy, the risks of these plastics could be serious – some studies have linked high exposure to cancer risk and disrupting our hormones.

In animal studies, the particles have been shown to affect metabolism, gut bacteria and the immune system

🏡Using specialist equipment, they measured a typical family home and found the highest concentration of it was in the bedroom of the family’s eight-year-old daughter, whose room was decorated with plastic-based bedding, carpet and soft toys

👁️ The largest microplastics can be seen by the naked eye, but many of them are small enough to act like specks of dust which we can inadvertently breathe in or eat in food. 

The smallest particles are called nanoplastics - they can make their way deep into the human body

❌ Microplastics are  one of the greatest manmade disasters of our time , according to the Natural History Museum. 

That’s bad news, given they are also everywhere; in tap water, the food you buy, the clothes you wear and the air you breathe

Ke Cheng, a professor of regenerative medicine at North Carolina State University, points out that the procedures are invasive

⚡️Why getting cold this winter could be the secret to better health

🧊 It might be a good idea to crawl out from under the blanket, turn down the thermostat and teach your body to warm up instead.

Read the full story 👇

Another upside is the well-documented sense of euphoria that follows a cold swim or shower. 

🧠In 2018, a report said that a woman who had experienced depression and anxiety for many years was able to stop taking medication after taking up regular wild swimming

🚿A similar effect can be achieved with just a cold shower.

One study found that those who ended every warm shower with 30-90 seconds of cold water for a month were 30 percent  less likely to take time off work for sickness than those who took normal warm showers

Wild swimming and activities with a short sharp shock of cold can also be great for the immune system. 

⚡️One study found that the initial rush of adrenaline was quickly followed by an increase in anti-inflammatory chemicals in the blood, which tamp down the immune response

🏊‍♀️Wild swimming is potentially an efficient way to boost your brown fat.

A new study from the University of Copenhagen found that regular cold water swimmers’ brown fat burns more calories when cold than people who weren’t used to the cold

Regular cold exposure increases brown fat activity, not just when the body is cold but for several hours afterwards.

🥶That suggests that getting chilly may be an easy way to burn a few calories with minimum effort

Brown fat is packed with mitochondria, tiny cellular powerplants that burn glucose to produce heat. When the temperature drops, these factories spring into action. 

🌡️Some studies suggest a link between our centrally-heated lives and the rise in obesity

➡️The body has to work to generate heat when you cool down. 

One way it does this is by activating stores of brown fat. Unlike white fat, brown fat doesn’t store calories - it burns them

❄️As the temperatures drop and the nights start to draw in, the last thing on most people’s minds is finding ways to feel colder.

But exposure to the cold is good for your health - from weight loss to increased immunity

Because the Wycherleys were given a public funeral, paid for out of council funds, their ashes were scattered in a memorial garden, with no marker to commemorate the lives that were taken from them.

🗣️A Sky spokesman said:  Landscapers doesnt seek to minimise the seriousness of the crimes of Susan and Christopher Edwards. The drama is a character driven series focused on the motivations of those involved, and asks serious questions about personal and moral responsibility.

Bill Wycherley’s few surviving relatives are equally unhappy about the idea of a dark comedy being made out of the murders.

One relative said,  It’s not that long since they found the bodies; it seems too soon to do a TV series like this.
This is really weird, but I have been here all this time and I have lived with them in my garden but they aren’t here any more. Why move out when nothing has changed?
Sitting barefoot in a leather armchair in her lounge, hugging her knees to her chest, Sue addresses the obvious question: what made her stay?

Bramley, who works as a nurse in a GP surgery, attended most days of the trial, and found the experience deeply disturbing. 

She had hoped that seeing the couple in person would help her to understand them, but,  they were expressionless, emotionless.

While the story is indisputably dark, as well as extraordinary, tragic and downright weird, those who are still affected by the Edwardses’ wicked crime are united in their insistence that funny’ is not a word that can be applied to it

Sue Bramley was not surprised when a production company contacted her, saying,  I’d always said they could make a film out of this. 

But what has disturbed her is the billing of the Sky drama as an exhilarating and darkly funny exploration of love and fantasy’.

While greed was undoubtedly a motive for the murders, so was revenge. 

Susan had been nursing a grudge against her parents because she felt they had cheated her out of an inheritance left to her by a step-grandmother but which ended up in her parents’ hands.
Their hobby was to buy signed photographs and other memorabilia of Hollywood greats.

Christopher and Susan were completely self-contained, but there was one thing they did like to spend money on.

It was a large part of the reason they decided to murder the Wycherleys...

The truth about what really happened to the Wycherleys finally emerged in 2013.

Both are now serving life sentences for double murder.

Until 2005, the house was being tended by Susan and Christopher Edwards, an oddball couple who murdered Susan’s parents, Bill and Pat Wycherley, spending the next 15 years pretending they were still alive so they could help themselves to their money.

When the Bramleys started renting the property in 2006, neither they nor anyone else in the community had any idea that it was the scene of one of the most peculiar murders in recent criminal history, carried out by the most unlikely of killers.

Sue Bramley nods at the spot in her garden where the skeletal remains of her house’s previous occupants were discovered.

It was eight years ago, and she will never forget it as long as she lives

The land registry has, it says, paid out £3.5 million in compensation in such cases in the past 12 months, up 40 percent  on the previous year. 

🏡 Hall may get his compensation via this route, but the house, once registered, belongs to the new purchaser
➡️ The licence was also sufficient to persuade a solicitor to do the legal work on the transfer of ownership

💸 With this key official document in his possession, the fraudster was able to convince a bank to open an account for him in the name of Mike Hall into which he received the funds the new owners paid for the property

🕵️‍♀️The swindle was sophisticated. 

First the scammer had ordered a duplicate driving licence in Hall’s name from the DVLA, to be posted to the address they had on record – the empty Luton property. 

Then he managed to change the picture on it

🏡The Land Registry said the house had been sold by one Mike Hall the previous month.

Only it wasn’t the real Hall, but a scammer pretending to be him
🚨 When he reported the theft of his home to the police, they informed him it was a civil matter, to do with the Land Registry, and not a crime, so there was nothing they could do to help

Is it just a nightmare?

❌ The Revd Mike Hall was wide awake when he drove from where he had been working in Wales to the terraced house he had owned in Luton for 31 years, only to be locked out and told he was trespassing by a man claiming to be the new owner’s father

It is every homeowner’s worst nightmare. 

🔑 You are at your front door, put the key in the lock, and it won’t open. 

Through the window you see someone has replaced your possessions with their own. 

They then inform you that your home is now officially theirs

📞 First they tried to swindle you over the phone.
💻 Then they tried to trick you online.

🏡 Now con artists are targeting your bricks and mortar.

Heres how scammers are stealing homes.

 In Virginia, they duly welcomed us by having us attempt their  E  (endurance) course at the hottest point of the day. 

➡️  Two of our boys instantly broke their all-time record

🚁 In some ways, the US philosophy is:  Why would we need to walk anywhere when we could just get a helicopter or vehicle?  

 Well, we haven’t got that luxury, so we train for the worst and make sure we can do it without hardware as backup
🇺🇸  We took them to Scotland for mountain training, which included a trek up Ben Nevis in full kit. Halfway up, we had to start carrying the Americans’ kit – they just couldn’t handle it

The US Marines contains some outstanding soldiers and some outstanding regiments but, compared like-for-like, the Royal Marines tended to be fitter, more tactically intelligent and, most importantly, able to push themselves far further than their US counterparts

🎖️ I spent almost six years in the Royal Marines, working in Iraq, Somalia, Egypt and Afghanistan 

 Training exercises with our US counterparts were fairly regular and they generally ended the same way: with the British coming out on top in just about every area

As a British soldier, there’s no feeling quite like getting one over on the Americans. All that money, all that tech  says Gareth.

☕️One solution could be recycled coffee grounds converted into  logs  which burn 20 percent  hotter and longer than kiln-dried wood. 

– but be warned, they have quite a distinct smell

✖️If you still can’t give up your wood burner, there are ways to limit the damage.

🟢Another promising option is bioethanol fires, which burn ethanol – a renewable and green fuel derived from the fermentation of crops and food waste

♨️Emissions from other heat sources, are much lower than even the newest and most efficient wood stoves.

This includes heat pumps, district heating, oil boilers and even gas boilers, which the Government wants to phase out

The particles are especially harmful to the more delicate lungs of older and younger people. 

🗣️ Burning wood and coal in a stove or on an open fire releases PM 2.5, the most worrying form of air pollution to human health,  says Eluned Hughes

➡️But even stoves which adhere to the EU rules are allowed to emit 750 times more tiny particle pollution than a modern HGV truck

🔥Wood-burning stoves are among the most lusted-after interiors items.

♀️What happens to a womans heart when she takes on too much at work and home?
🔎Read the full story to find out seven ways to combat twin stress and look after your heart here ⬇️

🗣️ Being a great parent and being good at your job was easier when life was separated between work and home,  says Christine Armstrong, researcher and vlogger on the Future of Work at Armstrong & Partners
While the post-pandemic WFH lifestyle may be a godsend for working women practically, it may well be detrimental to our health physically, overloading our bodies - and our hearts – with toxic stress

🗣️ Palpitations, headaches, trouble sleeping, comfort eating, sudden weight loss or weight gain, easily getting angry or feeling numb are all symptoms of stress and women need to be aware of them,  says senior cardiac nurse Regina Giblin

During the pandemic, these stresses increased exponentially with women shouldering much of the emotional and physical labour of looking after the family as well as working…

The ripple effect is still ongoing

This twin stress, dubbed in the study as  psychosocial stress  can be lethal, doing more damage to women’s hearts than the effects of:

🔴Drinking
🔴Smoking 
🔴Depression
🔴High cholesterol
The study revealed that the combined strains of holding down a job and keeping up with social responsibilities increases the risk of coronary heart disease (CHD) for women
🤯It doesnt take a scientist to tell us that working hard while caring for a family can be highly stressful, but a new study reveals the true health cost to women’s hearts of trying to do both well

♀️As women try to balance their careers with their domestic lives, the pressure may be doing more harm than drinking, smoking or cholesterol. 

What happens to a woman’s heart when she takes on too much at work and home?

Read the full dispatch👇

🌊Coastal erosion also means the water is encroaching on people’s homes. 

The shoreline is littered with enormous tractor tyres, shipping containers and industrial sandbags. 

Some houses have already been lost, as have historical burial sites

🐻‍❄️A lack of sea ice means it is much harder for polar bears to hunt.

They eat ringed seals, stalking them on ice floes. The odds are now stacked in favour of the seals, so the bears have sought new hunting grounds

Data from the National Oceanic Atmospheric Association shows that 50 years ago an average Autumn would see temperatures of -11.4°C. 

➡️ Today, the average is -4.7°C

🧊 Nowhere is warming faster than the Arctic and few places are seeing the devastating impacts as clearly as Utqiagvik.

 We should have an ocean full of ice by now. But it is still 200 miles away.  said Colleen Akpik-Lemen, director of the Iñupiat Heritage Centre

Coastal erosion is nibbling away the edge of the town, which sits just three metres above sea level.

🌧️The summer of 2019 was the wettest on record, with twice as much rain as usual, thawing the permafrost far deeper than before

Home to the Iñupiat people for 1,500 years, this final frontier is one of the earliest settlements in America. 

➡️There is no road in or out of the town, formerly known as Barrow

✖️In Utqiagvik, houses built on permafrost are sinking into the ground, underground cellars are flooding.

💡Under a new scheme overseen by the United Nations, countries are able to meet their climate goals by trading carbon credits.

This allows buyers to keep on polluting through paying for an emissions cut elsewhere

But tradable carbon offsets remain controversial and have been described as a licence to pollute. 

🗣️ Al Gore last week warned that carbon offsets  can’t be a get-out-of-jail-free card

While developed economies’ contributions are falling, the global impact is not enough to tip the balance as pollution grows in emerging markets.

➡️ IETA says Article 6 could more than half the cost of imposing the national climate goals agreed in Paris

🗣️  Basically it will make or break the Paris agreement in terms of its ability to achieve mitigation. 

A failure to agree to such a market would stop many countries being able to reach net zero emissions, Forrister warns

🟢 Countries want to level the playing field between carbon markets and create a new offsetting system.

This would allow a polluter to pay for green projects and count it towards their own climate goal - effectively trading their way to net zero

Cop26 negotiators could make progress on Article 6 of the Paris Agreement.

➡️ This acknowledges the need for international carbon markets to help slash emissions

🌍 Optimism over making substantial progress by the end of the Cop26 summit is in short supply.

But there are hopes of a breakthrough in one area: a global carbon market

⁉️So has the past 12 months been unusually bad for extreme weather?
 
It’s hard to say yet unequivocally - but it does appear to be part of a longer-term trend of weather change

🌪️Since the start of the 2020 season, 50 named storms have formed over the Atlantic, a record number.
 
Climate scientists think the number of storms isn’t necessarily increasing because of climate change, but their severity may be

🌧️Last year 1.5 million people in East Africa were forced from their homes by flooding with almost six million affected overall. More than 400 people were killed.
 
In 2021, severe floods were seen in Europe, with a  once in a millennium  event killing at least 230 people

This trend is because most of these fires happened in grassland in Africa and Asia which is being converted to agricultural land and also becoming less flammable.
 
🌏But at the same time forest fires in Australia, Europe, and the western US are going up

🔥Globally, long-term fire trends have not been going in the direction you might expect - the overall area burned has decreased in recent decades.
 
But experts say this shouldn’t be used to argue that climate change hasn’t made fires worse

How does 2021 compare so far on temperature?
 
Weve experienced the hottest months on record globally compared to pre-industrial age⬇️

🗓️Officially, 2020 was the second-hottest year on record, behind 2016.
 
Last summer Death Valley in California recorded a temperature of 54.4C - the hottest measured on earth since 1931

An Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change earlier this year found that human influence on the climate was  unequivocal .
 
☀️The world had already warmed by 1.1C and temperature goals were in severe danger of being breached

🌍The database also shows another 62.2m people have seen their lives significantly affected, for example through homelessness or injuries.
 
💰The global bill of damages from extreme weather in 2021 so far stands at over £93bn

5,520+ people have died due to extreme weather so far this year globally, according to the EM-DAT database of disasters.
 
🔎This figure is likely to be an underestimate of the true death toll - the full impact of 2021’s heatwaves, storms and floods have not yet been assessed

Ahead of the Cop26, scientists are warning that extreme weather events are becoming more frequent.
 
🗣️Professor Peter Stott, of the Met Office Hadley Centre, said:  What seems clear to me is that in recent years weve seen the effects of climate change becoming manifest

🌡️2021 has seen all parts of the world - from the US to Africa, the Middle East and Asia - experience at least one month with average heat higher than at any point since 1880.
 
A total of 549 record monthly temperatures have been seen already by September

⚠️The world has been hit by record temperatures and devastating weather in 2021.
 
Here are the worrying consequences of climate change ahead of Cop26

🎓The Raffles Institution is leading the race to secure coveted places at our top universities. 

So, what the secret of its success?
🚨BREAKING: Extinction Rebellion protesters break into UKs biggest oil refinery

This school is no walk in the playground 

Read more ⬇️

As one anonymous former pupil wrote in a blog:

 🗣️As a result of bearing the lion’s share of pressure, the school on A-level results day can be an emotional place, with people sobbing in corners, berating themselves after failing to secure perfect scores, or crowing jubilantly

It’s so stressful. Some parents even take unpaid leave for the last month [before the exam] to support their children,  says Linda. 

➗  This year, kids were coming out of their exams crying and vomiting. It was all over one maths question

This is no exam factory - GCSEs have been replaced with a 6-year programme without testing.

But 16-year-old angst has been replaced by pre-teen anxiety as the pupils are selected based on their Primary School Leaving Examination, which all Singaporean children take aged 12

From 13, pupils study philosophy to mould them into  critical, rational thinkers . 

🔬Kids are encouraged to pursue enrichment programmes, including one on water sustainability and another on  technology incubation , where they  learn how to turn their tech dreams into reality

🔴Competitiveness is at the centre of the Raffles world – there is a focus on maths, coding and commercial business, especially with relevance to China. 

Leadership skills are strongly emphasised, which might explain why several Singaporean prime ministers are alumni

The boys school was founded in 1823 by Sir Stamford Raffles, the British founder of Singapore, and girls were introduced in 1879. 

Curiously, the first headmaster, John Henry Moor, was the great-great-great-great grandfather of Canadian PM Justin Trudeau

And then there are the local Singaporean schools run by the government such as Raffles.

💸Their fees are much lower, around $300 (or £160) a month.

Globally, they are considered to provide the best education in the world

First it’s important to understand the dual carriageway education system driving Singapore.

41 percent  of Singapores population are expats. 

➡️Largely barred from entering the Singaporean education system, they have turned to the oversubscribed international schools

🇸🇬 Singapore has always been known for the quality of its education.

British head teachers are scrabbling to understand its success as UK schools slide down the OECD’s global education rankings - this year described as an  average performer

🏫The Raffles Institution, Singapore’s oldest school, has scooped 5th position in the league table ranking schools by how many pupils they send to Oxbridge.

Out of the 263 pupils who applied last year, 52 won places

❓So, what the secret of its success?

Hes taking a very big bet on growth and if that growth doesnt work out, he could some unstuck

Mass testing of mostly healthy people is an intrusive, pointless and expensive exercise  | Telegraph View

Perhaps we are simply returning to Edwardian-style delivery boys – when daily fresh produce was delivered by someone you trusted right to the door 

🥑 Just replace lard with avocado and it could be a case of what goes around comes around after all

But perhaps I’m being overly doomful 

 As delivery services diversify, surely suppliers will become more niche? 

🚲 Maybe butchers will get back on their bikes?

I find the whole phenomenon – let alone my spineless collusion with it – rather horrifying 

🍨 I grew up in the Kent countryside. One winter my little brother cycled six miles to Sevenoaks to get his mitts on a Wall’s mint Viennetta
Once you get accustomed to door-to-door deliveries it’s fiendishly hard to go back. It’s not as if most of us adore wandering soulless superstore aisles

🏙️ All around, I see my urban friends fall to the devilish lure of the new convenience-high, cardiovascular-low normality. 

 You no longer need to  ask the universe  to fulfil your innermost yearnings, Just Eat and Amazon will oblige instead
But then the delivery economy has worked its strange alchemy on all of us. Before the pandemic, Deliveroo and Uber Eats were alien concepts to our household

You might suspect there’s a north-south divide on this healthy delicacy; but, nope, the citizens of Glasgow rate it second of all their sudden culinary desires 

➡️ In Newcastle, birthplace of the  pizza doughnut , it ranks at number four

🛒Waitrose, which makes its groceries available via Deliveroo, has reported that the avocado is among the top five items requested in cities where the store’s wares are available. 

Furthermore, it’s the number one demand in Oxford, Cambridge and Brighton

However, the most successful part of Britain’s Covid-19 response was the vaccine programme💉

It is estimated to have saved 112,000 lives in England alone and protected nearly 50 million people in the UK

Britain’s pandemic planning was also too heavily based on influenza, and had failed to incorporate lessons from outbreaks of Sars, Mers and Ebola.

➡️The 2019 National Risk Register concluded an emerging virus would lead to a maximum of 100 deaths

✈️Meanwhile, a failure to shut borders allowed an influx of new cases.

A study by Imperial College found that 33 percent  of cases during the first wave were introduced from Spain and 29 percent  were introduced from France

The lack of testing was particularly damaging for care homes.

Unaware of the true scale of spread, ministers and scientists adopted a  fatalistic  approach of trying to manage Covid-19, rather than stop it. 

⚠️This  amounted in practice  to accepting herd immunity through infection, the report concluded

 The UK was reduced to understanding the spread by waiting for people to be so sick that they needed to be admitted to hospital

Today, ensuring the survival of these houses and dynasties means deciding what traditions should remain and evolve — from the Queen facing calls to adapt to a more modern, to aristocrats challenging the misogynistic rules of primogeniture

There is a huge pressure on the people who own these houses,  says Aslet.
 
 If your family has been seated in this place for 500 years, you don’t want to be the [one] who messes up - That is a huge burden on some of these people

📺 The National Trust thinks people arent so interested in the houses [as] the outdoors. Im not sure thats entirely true: look at the huge success of things like Downton Abbey. People are so fascinated

✅The houses that have remained in private hands, not sold out or bequeathed to the National Trust, are the best surviving.
 
 The National Trust is accused of having rather lost its way,  Aslet says.
 
 Its role has been overtaken by private houses

In present times, the dial has changed again.

Luxury in the age of the mobile phone is defined by privacy - this has spurred on a revival in country houses.

🔒 People don’t really know what you’re doing. If you have an estate, then you have a very nice area of your own

👑In the Tudor period, great displays of gold and silver plates were laid out for the world to see - it was part of the notion of magnificence’, championed by James I.
 
That idea endured until the Regency period, when luxury was defined by lavish, Bridgerton-style opulence

🪙The country house has existed as an expression of might for hundreds of years.
 
In the Middle Ages and Renaissance periods, tapestries lining the walls were status symbols.
 
Furniture was hand-crafted and therefore a symbol of wealth

📍From the great hall of Stokesay Castle, to the Baroque stylings of Burghley House - the book tells the history of myriad exceptional British houses and the families that inhabited them.

Each reveals themes of power and expectation that cut to the core of society

The people who lived in these houses behaved in a way that was totally unlike that of the population  says Aslet.
 
💎What  from the outside appears to be extraordinarily privileged and have amazing artworks and plates of gold... but actually, does it make human happiness?

Esteemed writer and historian, Clive Aslet, has harboured a love of British country houses since the 80s.
 
📚After 40 years of visiting and writing about grand homes, he has poured his knowledge into a new book, The Story of the Country House’

👀The popularity of TV shows including The Crown, Downton Abbey and Bridgerton has shown the general public is going quite mad for country houses and the lifestyles of their occupants.
 
What is life like inside Britain’s grandest country houses?

💉More than 35 million across England are eligible for free flu vaccines this year, while another 28 million are set to be offered Covid booster jabs.

Whos eligible and where to go⬇️

💉Those eligible for flu jabs can book their free NHS flu vaccine via pharmacies or they can wait for their GP surgery to contact them.
 
💉Those eligible for a coronavirus booster jab are being told to wait until they are contacted

Sajid Javid, the Health Secretary, said:  This year we are rolling out the largest flu vaccine programme in our history, alongside the new Covid-19 booster vaccine... both are important to provide vital protection not only to yourself, but also your loved ones

Health officials expressed concern that the public underestimate the combined threats of Covid and the flu.
 
🌏Polling of 3,000 adults found 1/3 were unaware that Covid and flu could circulate at the same time

💉As a result, the NHS is about to embark on the biggest rollout of flu jabs in its history.
 
Everyone over the age of 50 and below the age of 16 will be offered vaccines, along with pregnant women, health and care workers, and millions with underlying health conditions

🔎Officials highlighted modelling from the Academy of Medical Sciences, which suggests this winter the UK could see between 15,000 and 60,000 flu deaths.
 
This compares with an average of 11,000 deaths a year in the five years before the pandemic

Professor Jonathan Van-Tam, deputy chief medical officer, said:  Not many people got flu last year because of Covid-19 restrictions...
 
🦠 We will see flu circulating this winter; it might be higher than usual and that makes it a significant public health concern

🔬Every year WHO and EU identify which strains are likely to be prevalent for that year’s flu season and new vaccines are produced to protect against these strains.
 
But with a drop in samples, the government is pessimistic about how effective this year’s jab will be

📉Cases of flu in the community went down by 95 percent  in 2020 - mainly due to Covid measures limiting interaction.
 
 Not only does this mean many of us have not built up a natural immunity... It also presents a second challenge - how to produce an effective jab  said @lauradonnlee

Have you been impacted by the fuel shortage?

It was not until Friday, Sept 24 that the stock crisis snowballed, with demand more than doubling.

Daily road fuel sales lept from 15,000 litres per station in the week prior to Sept 24 to more than 35,000

⛽️By Sept 25, pumps across the country were empty

📉Yet from Sept 1, forecourts across the UK began to see a steady and pronounced decline in fuel stocks.
 
By Sept 16 – a week before panic-buying began – average stock levels had fallen from 40 percent  to 34 percent 
 
By Sept 23 stock levels were already at 32 percent

According to the figures released on Thursday by the Department for Business, Enterprise and Industrial Strategy, deliveries for road fuel remained steady throughout the summer.
 
The constant supply meant pump stock levels hovered at 40 percent  full, at most rising or falling by 1-2 percent

Ministers rolled out E10, which is blended with a minimum of 5.5 percent  biofuel, as the standard unleaded petrol from Sept 1.
 
🟢The move was an interim step to help the UK reach its target of net zero emissions by 2030

For weeks we had been emptying our tanks of E5, the old fuel, as fast as we could to get ready for E10. We had all run our petrol stocks down...
 
🚛 Then the shortage of HGV drivers meant we couldn’t get supplies quickly enough  the chairman said

❌When panic buying began, garages found they did not have enough in storage tanks to keep up with demand.

 I don’t blame the Government particularly but the E10 switchover clearly had an unintended consequence  said Brian Madderson, chairman of the Petrol Retailers Association

⚠️Government figures reveal fuel deliveries to petrol stations remained steady over the summer despite warnings of a lack of HGV drivers.
 
Yet the amount of spare fuel stored fell sharply by up to 12 percent  after Sept 1, when the Government introduced greener E10 fuel as the standard

🔴EXCLUSIVE: The Government’s switch to greener petrol was a  major factor  behind the fuel crisis, industry chiefs reveal.

Petrol retailers were emptying their tanks’ for the switchover to E10 fuel when garages were swiftly drained by panic buying

⚖️Having more renewables on the system can make it harder to manage, however, as they depend on the weather and also do not provide inertia

💡The UKs power system has been transformed in recent years amid efforts to tackle climate change.
 
Coal generated 1/5 of UK electricity in 2015 but this fell to less than 2 percent  in 2020, with wind power picking up much of the slack

Wholesale gas prices have risen more than six-fold on normal, leading to a more than four-fold increase in wholesale electricity prices.
 
📈The price cap on energy bills has already risen £139 to £1,277 and experts predict it could rise by another almost £400 in April
❌The ESO warned in July that Britain should prepare for constrained power supplies over winter - with nuclear power plants shutting down and demand bouncing back from the pandemic
🔥The countrys few remaining coal-fired power stations are also likely to run more frequently than last year, National Grid added, due to the prices they can earn to fill in gaps in supply

A key factor leading to the cut is understood to be a fire at a converter station in Sellindge, Kent.
 
🇫🇷The blaze knocked out the IFA interconnector bringing in about 2GW of power from France.
 
Half is expected to be back online this month, the rest not until late March 2022
⚠️Costs are ultimately passed onto household bills - a further pressure when bills are climbing due to soaring wholesale costs of natural gas and electricity

⚡️The National Grid’s electricity system operator (ESO) believes supply will meet demand - but has cut its forecast of buffer supply.
 
Officials are also warning of high costs getting power generators to fire up at short notice to help balance the system

📂A 2018 study published in the BMJ showed that both zero alcohol and excessive consumption increased the risk of dementia, while moderate alcohol consumption – no more than 14 units a week – was associated with a lower risk of dementia

But while a little consumption may be acceptable, Prof Frost still warns against three or more alcoholic drinks a day.

🍻 Our research casts no doubts on the well-established harmful effects of excessive drinking

🍺The Professor says that the UK chief medical officers’ guidelines, which advise it is safest to not drink regularly more than 14 units per week, spread over three days or more, are a good set of guidelines to follow
🍷Prof Frost goes further, adding that a glass of wine or beer with dinner can no longer be deemed as unsafe

🗣️ We don’t think the claim that the only safe alcohol intake is zero is true as it wasn’t based on a sound methodological approach  says Professor Chris Frost, of the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine

A paper published in The Lancet in 2019 claimed that even light drinking patterns increased blood pressure and the chances of having a stroke. 

❌However, a new paper claims that this analysis was flawed

🍷 The health risks of alcohol have been hammered home for years.

But new research suggests a drink with dinner can no longer be deemed unsafe

⚡️ Tired of being tired? How to decode your fatigue

👑 Is a beauty range on the cards for the ex-Royals? 

 If Meghan were to launch and back her own beauty range with the company, it would be an extremely clever move

Fatigue is like a puzzle. Certain steps will be critical for some and may not be important for somebody else,  Alex says.

See the full list of key steps to healing here 👇

Stable blood-sugar levels are also critical.

❌Leaving too long a gap between meals or eating foods that are absorbed too quickly, such as refined carbohydrates, will cause a spike in our blood-sugar levels, followed by a crash

Optimising your digestion is another step.

If your body isn’t breaking down and absorbing energy from your food, then it is like a car with insufficient fuel supply.

Consider factors such as how much your chew your food, and if you eat in a calm, relaxed environment 🥣

Next, understand your personality, and how your approach to life could be inherently draining.

👉 For example, the drive to get things right is more important for perfectionists, however much their body may beg for care

📝 Alex uses a 12-step plan to heal people, with the first urging you to take responsibility to change your situation. 

Following that, you need to rule out medical issues that could be causing fatigue with a doctor

Alex says the natural human state should be one of zest for life. 

➡️If you’re routinely waking up and having to motivate yourself to get out of bed, or use coffee to kick-start your system, the question is why

❓Do you have fatigue? 

 If you slow down, rest, and months later, you’re still fatigued, there’s something going on that needs to be understood,  Alex says.

 Generally, you need to have had symptoms for at least 3 months to be diagnosed
💬  For a lot of people, going through the pandemic has been enormously depleting – when our system goes into a state of sustained overload, it becomes drained,  Alex says

⚠️ Fatigue currently impacts around 30 million people across the world, and nearly half say they feel too exhausted to function.

It is an epidemic within a pandemic.

Expert Alex Howard has revealed key steps to fixing it

If women’s voices alone could have stopped this violence, it would have ended long ago. We need more men now to mobilise themselves – and each other – to tackle this epidemic  | Writes @VeraBaird

So, what must happen now? The police, of all institutions, need to lead by example. 

 They need to police their own

These criminal justice failings don’t exist in isolation. They reflect the enduring sexism and misogyny entrenched in our wider culture  

 Women are undervalued as people, professionals and figures of authority and too readily regarded as figures principally of sexual value

The terrible fate of Sarah Everard will inevitably undermine women’s faith in policing further still. Winning back their confidence will be a long and steep climb for police. 

 They need to start today

Violence against women and girls is a cause of inequality as well as a result of it. That women are far more often in fear of violence and subject to abuse is the last great inequality that we must tackle. 

⚫️ Safety is a right, not a privilege
We’ve made huge strides in gender equality during recent decades. But until a woman is safe from sexual violence, her success in work or education hangs by a thread

The depressing truth is the police simply don’t prioritise policing violence (sexual or otherwise) against women and girls  

✍️Writes @VeraBaird, the Victims Commissioner for England and Wales

🔴The legal case argued that allowing abortion for Down’s syndrome up until birth stereotypes and demeans’ people and is incompatible with the European Convention on Human Rights, and that this section of the UK’s 1967 Abortion Act should be removed

Heidi Crowter, who has Down’s syndrome, has challenged the 1967 law.

She has led a campaign called Don’t Screen Us Out, which has raised more than £100,000 from 3,000 people to challenge the late abortion provision, which Crowter says doesn’t respect my life’, in the high court
➡️Fifty years ago, Down’s syndrome was considered a serious disability - now most of the associated complications, including learning difficulties, can be fully or partially treated

🔴The Down’s syndrome community is now fighting a rearguard action to change the narrative and make people aware that, thanks to modern medicine, their children can attend mainstream schools, live independently and enjoy a life expectancy similar to the rest of us

Ahead of the introduction of the NIPT test, nuchal translucency ultrasound scanning had been offered with a test for blood biomarkers associated with Down’s syndrome for around 20 years.
 
The use of these tests has halved the number of babies born in the UK with Down’s syndrome

📉The rate of Down’s syndrome births is falling fast.
One study saw a 54 percent  decline in Down’s syndrome births in Europe between 2011 - 2015.
 
Ranging from:
🇪🇸83 percent  fall in Spain, to
🇲🇹0 percent  in Malta, where abortion is banned

🇩🇰In countries such as Denmark, which introduced NIPT screening in 2006, more than 95 percent  of affected pregnancies are aborted.
 
🇮🇸In Iceland, no affected babies are believed to have been born since 2017

NIPT testing is carried out in the first three months of pregnancy - it is 99 percent  accurate in picking up cells carrying Down’s syndrome.
 
Under the current 1967 Abortion Act, any Down’s syndrome baby that is undetected through the screening can be legally aborted up until birth

In countries where early screening is routinely offered, almost all women opt to abort the affected unborn baby and try again.
 
🔴The global Down’s syndrome population is therefore plummeting

🩸Since July, all pregnant women in England have been routinely offered NIPT (non-invasive prenatal testing) screening, a blood test which detects the rogue extra copy of chromosome 21 that causes Down’s syndrome.
 
The test has been offered in Scotland since January

🔴Could this be the last generation of Downs syndrome children?
 
Globally, the Down’s syndrome population is plummeting - leading to suggestions we may be witnessing the elimination of the condition

Miss Everards parents must forever live with the knowledge that, just days before Couzens murdered their daughter, police had everything they needed to arrest him on suspicion of a crime that would have ended his career

Couzens gave police one more chance to catch him when he returned to his habit of flashing just days before he murdered Miss Everard.

It was the last – and biggest – missed chance
Although he was vetted, the flashing incident did not come to light and he was able to walk straight into a new job

🔴A porous vetting process

Despite Kent Polices failure to arrest Couzens, the fact that he had been identified as a suspected flasher might still have come to light when he applied to transfer to the Metropolitan Police in 2018

🔴Flashing while driving

Couzens is now known to have repeatedly exposed himself while driving – an offence which would almost certainly have ended his police career if it had been detected at the time

If Couzens behaviour had been reported at the time, he might have been thrown out of the force years before he used his warrant card to coax Miss Everard into his car.

It was the first of several missed opportunities to stop him

➡️Gave women the creeps – but behaviour went unreported

Couzens reportedly  gave women the creeps  but, in the male-dominated world of policing, none of the women made a formal complaint against him

Three days before he abducted Sarah Everard, Couzens exposed himself at a McDonalds drive-thru restaurant. Staff reported the incident to police, who identified his car via CCTV.

❌He was not arrested, leaving him free to kidnap, rape and murder

🔴Wayne Couzens had such a reputation for sexual deviance that he was known to his colleagues as  the rapist .

Identified as the suspect in an indecent exposure case six years ago, it was also an open secret that he was a drug user with a taste for extreme pornography

What were the police blunders that left Wayne Couzens free to murder Sarah Everard?

Failings in vetting, whistleblowing and straightforward policing were all to blame for the failure to stop the killer.

🔎Read Dawn Cokers full testimony on her struggle with menopause in the workplace here 👇
🗣️ My symptoms were debilitating and embarrassing but I felt I couldn’t speak to anyone, male or female, about what I was going through
🪟 All my direct line managers were men, who didn’t fully understand why sometimes I needed to go home early, sit near a window for fresh air or have a fan on my desk
💼Even today, there is  precious little  understanding of the menopause in the workplace, Dawn says, but in the nineties there was  even less
➡️According to Dawn, her colleagues knew she’d had a medical issue but, because she was a workaholic and was keeping the show on the road, no one fully realised what she was going through
