⚡️ How Russia’s Z’ has become the emblem of a propaganda war

❓What fate now, then, awaits  Z : should it go on to be associated with ever more atrocities in Ukraine, and the propaganda campaign of an increasingly totalitarian regime in Russia?

Read the full story👇

🇷🇺In St Petersburg,  Z  is displayed in huge neon signs on major buildings. 

Nor is it limited to Russia. In Belgrade, thousands of pro-Russian sympathisers marched over the weekend to back the invasions, many with placards bearing the three simple lines of the  Z

💬 Z’ doesn’t exist in the Cyrillic alphabet,  notes Sir Richard Evans, historian of modern Europe at Cambridge University.

 But it’s rapidly become widely used by Putin’s supporters

A Russian opposition activist posted pictures of a Z that Russian soldiers have formed from the insignia they claim are ripped from uniforms of killed Ukrainian soldiers.

In orchestrated videos circulating online, flag-waving Russians stand in serried ranks wearing the Z emblem

Its spread from the battlefield to the civilian front has been astonishing. 

Pictures show children back home in a Russian hospice led out to form a human  Z  snaking through the winter snow

➡️Now, however, Z has been appropriated and subverted, reports @harrydq 

It has been propelled from the practical insignia of a military marshalling yard to the emblem of a propaganda war unleashed by Moscow on the home front

🔴It is only a little more than a week since Russian armoured columns rolled south from Belarus into Ukraine, many bearing three stripes of tape forming  Z. 

Then, according to Ukrainian soldiers, it simply marked out units from Russia’s Eastern Military District

🇷🇺The letter  Z  has become an icon of support for the Russian invasion of Ukraine.

It has been daubed on Russian roads and walls, on bus shelters and cars – a public sign of devotion to Vladimir Putin and his campaign

In times of war, symbols matter🧵👇

Andriy Kononenko is a former assistant to The Telegraph’s reporters in Ukraine, who gave up his job running a language centre in Kyiv to volunteer as a reservist in the Ukrainian army

He shares his diary of a week at war ⤵️
Read the full diary from Andriy Kononenko here ⬇️

🔴 Saturday: Hoping against hope for a brave girl 

One my dearest, most dynamic colleagues has a five-year-old child. 

She also has cancer, Hodgkin’s lymphoma. She is 33.
 
The war started and she was asked to leave the hospital, so her treatment is not happening.

🔴 Friday: Trauma at the border 

 The queues are being managed by volunteers who don’t know how to handle stressed and traumatised people sensitively

🔴Thursday: A call to arms 

 Many people are not fleeing. Instead, they are arming themselves with hunting rifles, kalashnikovs, weapons that they have had stashed away since the Second World War

🔴Wednesday: Evacuating our desperate countrymen 

 We are supposed to be a territorial provisional unit and it is not really in our competence to be absorbing direct attacks from the enemy – at least not just yet. That might all come later

🔴 Tuesday: Under missile attack at our checkpoint 

 I was driving back from the house, a little late as I had forgotten my fleece, and was 200 yards away from the checkpoint when there was a huge flash in front of me, followed by another a few seconds later

🔴Monday: A close shave with saboteurs

 My biggest fear when I decided to volunteer as a soldier was that I might have to kill someone. Less than 48 hours after signing up, my nightmare nearly came true

In recent years Azov has produced perfect content for Russian state television, putting a face to the Kremlin’s claims about the rise of the far-right in Ukraine.

📸 Now, the well-oiled PR machine has been producing the  best-quality war videos capturing the attacks in real time

🔴 Azov rose to prominence at the start of the separatist insurgency in Ukraine in 2014. 

It never held much sway in Ukraine’s politics but videos of its occasional torch-lit marches have helped to feed the false Kremlin narrative of Ukrainians being neo-Nazis

🗣️ The true nightmare of Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe’s imprisonment – in her own words ⬇️

Being alone was awfully hard for me. [The guards] sometimes left the cell door open. They said they knew I was innocent. 

Read the extract in full here ⬇️

🗣️  I thought I was in a nightmare. 

 I could not believe I had been separated from Gisou. I missed her a lot. I missed bathing her, putting her to sleep. We had never been apart.... I wondered what she would do, how she would eat and sleep without me

They kept telling me I had lost my job and that if interrogation took too long my husband would leave me. 

 Once the interrogator brought his iPad and showed me fragments of Richard’s interview. I cried so much once that I fainted

There were days when they wanted me to say that my husband was a spy and that I worked for spy organisations, but I refused.  

 I was kept in solitary confinement for 40 days. The interrogators threatened to send Gisou to London if I did not co-operate

While I was in Kerman I had only one meeting with my family. 

After the meeting I felt awful. Gisou had changed. She had teethed. She didn’t recognise me. I didn’t recognise her either.

The interrogation started from the first day. In the first week I was interrogated every day. 

 I was not taken outside the cell except during interrogation hours and I was never granted the right to be out in the fresh air

🗣️  The cell toilet smelled so horrible that guards covered their noses when they came to distribute food. 

 I became sick at times. I had trouble breathing in that muggy air… a few times they brought drug addicts to that small cell with its dirty open toilet

Kerman Central Prison contained about 420 female prisoners. And it only had one quarantine cell. I was taken there. 

 All day long I heard the voices of all 420 women through the cell door. They echoed in my head, but I had no contact with them

The first night of detention I didn’t know where I was. I don’t remember what happened or what I did. 

 No one gave me any explanations. Nobody told me why they were treating me like that or why they took my child away from me

🔴 In 2016, Nazanin was arrested, separated from her 22-month-old daughter Gabriella (who she calls by her Farsi name, Gisou), charged with espionage and sent to solitary confinement in Kerman prison.

She described to activist Narges Mohammadi the agony of those first months 👇

🗣️  I thought I was in a nightmare - being confined and alone was severe torture 

The true nightmare of Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe’s imprisonment – in her own words.

Bingeing series you know to be trash because you can’t be bothered to change the channel.

2⃣Appearance

Prioritising comfort over all else. 

Wearing pyjamas outdoors. 

Worrying that washing your clothes will reduce their comfort.

The signs youre in Goblin Mode...

1⃣Food and drink

Eating pasta straight from the pan. 

Drinking Ribena for breakfast. 

Mayonnaise on pizza.

As lockdown restrictions ease, many of us are finding ourselves in strange and terrifying environments.  Parties.   The Tube.   The office.

It’s about a complete lack of aesthetic. Because why would a goblin care what they look like? Why would a goblin care about presentation?  says Dave McNamee, a self-proclaimed  real-life Goblin

The concept emerged on American social media during the pandemic but in recent weeks it has gone mainstream.

Goblin mode is a state of mind, an antidote to green juices, exercise, self-improvement

📻Some argue that the Buzzer is, in fact, part of Russia’s  Dead Hand  nuclear deterrent.

📻Is the Buzzer a numbers station?

 It’s essentially a frequency used by the Russian military to send messages. As for the buzzing itself, I believe it’s a channel marker – it keeps the frequency open,  Chris Smolinski, a shortwave radio expert has said

🇷🇺Usually it’s just a slur of static. But occasionally there is a barrage of apparently-random Russian words and numbers:

Read the full analysis here 👇

🟤 The younger generation is made up of, to be blunt, pragmatic kleptocrats. 

They may not dare to turn against Putin now, as their fortunes and freedom are in his hands, but they are unlikely to want to continue his crusade against the West if they can possibly avoid it

🟤 Sergei Shoigu

Defence minister Shoigu might be the kind of savvy strongman at once able to wield the muscle to topple Putin and also the political skills to reassure the rest of the elite

🟤 Mikhail Mishustin 

The 56-year-old could be the obvious choice for a technocratic successor, but he has not yet been at the centre of power long enough to build himself a network of clients and allies
❓ If mortality, muscle or machination do see Putin leave power, though, who might succeed him?

🌍 The most extreme option some in the West are openly discussing is the prospect of outright assassination.

This is highly unlikely, not least because the security precautions around  the Body , as Putin is known by his security detail, are massive, complex and comprehensive

In theory, Putin could be removed through the constitution. 

📜 Article 93 allows for impeachment on the basis of serious crimes. Yet that requires not only a two-thirds vote in both chambers of parliament, but also the consent of the Constitutional and Supreme Courts
🇷🇺 It is hard to see him standing down voluntarily. He periodically toyed with handing the presidency to a successor, perhaps retaining some  father of the nation  role

❔However, rumours are multiplying...

There are those in Russia and beyond wondering if mortality will do the job.

Might his strange terror of infection – never mind those comically long tables, be a sign he is suffering from a disease weakening his immune system?

On Monday, Putin signalled that he was willing to cut his losses.

Having previously indicated that he wanted to take the whole country – to, as he put it,  denazify  it – now he is only seeking Crimea and the south-eastern Donbas region

His brutal and ill-conceived war in Ukraine has left his army mired abroad and an economy reeling under unprecedented Western sanctions at home.

🇺🇦 That a military machine in which Putin has invested so much for so long could stumble and fall as soon as it steps into Ukraine
For 22 years he was the one constant of Russian politics, but no wonder people are thinking much more sharply not only about a Russia after Putin, but how that may be brought about...

🇷🇺 Russian missiles targeting civilian areas are using previously unseen technology to ensure they reach their targets.

Moscow is deploying specially designed decoy systems not used in previous conflicts ⬇️

🗣️ According to Professor Prof Jeffrey Lewis, a non-proliferation expert at the Middlebury Institute of International Studies in Monterey, California employing the decoys suggests  carelessness or urgency  by Russia as they will collected and studied by Western intelligence

US intelligence officials said that darts found in Ukraine are similar to Cold War decoys called  penetration aids .

🎯 Fitted to nuclear warheads since the Seventies, these decoys were designed to allow weapons to evade anti-missile systems so warheads could reach their targets

🟠 The Iskander missiles.

The devices are each about a foot long and coloured white with an orange tail and are powered by solid-fuel rocket motors.

Those in service with the Russian military can hit targets up to 500km (311 miles) away
📡 Intense heat sources in the base of the decoy rounds also emit powerful thermal signatures – thought to be by burning magnesium – which will attract these Ukrainian heat-seeking missiles

The darts are designed to protect ballistic rockets from air defence missiles that home in on their target with heat-seeking or radar technology.

📻 Each decoy contains electronics to send out radio signals to make Ukrainian radar-seeking missiles think the its the main weapon

🚀 These decoy darts are thought to be fired from mobile launchers in Belarus and Russia.

How do they work? ⬇️

💭 They were initially thought to be cluster bombs, based on their size and shape.

However, weapons experts believe that they are decoys that Russia has refused to sell to foreign nations as part of the Iskander system, so they would not be reverse-engineered by Western nations

🇷🇺 Moscow is deploying specially designed decoy systems not used in previous conflicts to ensure they reach their targets, according to US intelligence officials.

Iskander-M missiles are deploying decoy systems to fool Ukraine’s air defence systems...

⚡️ Creeping midlife weight gain – and how to stop it

We often think of 50 as an age when we should be slowing down, but 50 has been my best year ever. 

 Women of my age can feel forgotten or hidden, and it can be hard when your children fly the nest. But I see it as a time for me 

Read the full article ⬇

My advice to anyone who feels stuck or is struggling to shift an extra stone would be to take time for yourself, and to think about both your physical and emotional wellbeing.

 I’d also say to be curious in life, and open to new experiences

📚 I researched gut health and hormonal balance, and read lots of other books about food and health. It was the spark that changed my relationship with food.

🧠 I’ve trained my brain so that I make healthier choices. I understand my body more now

🗣  In April 2020, I started doing exercises, and my breasts became so tender that I thought about having a reduction.

 The soreness was due to being peri-menopausal.

 This time, I wasn’t motivated by how I looked, but by my health and how I felt

✍She writes,  I never saw myself as overweight or fat, but I knew I was heavier than I should be.

 I tried Weight Watchers, Slimming World and the Cambridge Diet, but nothing ever stuck.

 The weight would always creep back on

❌Once upon a time, realising that you had put on a few pounds was a catalyst for getting fit and healthy, but later in life, when the weight gain feels inevitable regardless of what you do, doing nothing becomes all too easy

🤷‍♂️If you’ve ever felt the shock of not recognising your own body, you already know that battling middle-age weight gain is as much psychological as it is physical.

Why does middle-age weight gain happen? And how can you stop it?

➡️They called it 007.

💊Mueller began looking for a simple drug to flush out the auto-antibodies from the bloodstream.

Eventually, after testing lots of existing compounds, he and his team discovered one that worked:  We were very euphoric.

Though their fields of expertise seem very different, they were linked by a strange coincidence: 

In both glaucoma and heart failure, a role is played by auto-antibodies’ – the product of an overzealous immune response that can end up damaging, rather than healing, the body
Desperate, she began casting around for alternative therapies and soon thought of Johannes Mueller, a distinguished heart doctor in Berlin

In spring last year Bettina Hohberger, an eye doctor at Erlangen University Hospital in eastern Germany, found herself confronted with every doctor’s nightmare.

Today, Dunn lives in Bristol, where she moved in 2015, back when she was a broken single mother, after her marriage ended. She has finally found happiness but it has taken years

Dunn is now 49. 

She has spent four decades chasing a dream of her father – the exciting and yet unreliable notion of him – she says, and as a result she has been unable to hold down healthy relationships. 

Her brother cut their father off from a very young age
It was a dark time, but, as it turns out, the most destructive effect of her father’s decision to opt out of conventional life to find his true essence’ was still to come

Disciples, Rajneesh preached, could live in love’, which meant having as much guilt-free sex as they desired. 

Children were seen as an obstruction to their parents’ sexual journey.

It was an enticing sell for Dunn’s father, an established serial adulterer.

Disciples were known as sannyasins.

They were encouraged to have vasectomies and sterilisations and hand over vast sums of money – many gave their life savings. 

By the late 70s and early 80s, most followers were well-educated, middle-class Americans and Europeans

Lily Dunn’s father Philip Dunn was among thousands of people worldwide to join the movement led by Bhagwan Shree Rajneesh, a man with a long beard, flowing robes of his own and, later, 96 Rolls-Royces

When Lily Dunn was six her father left the family to join a cult. 

She describes the impact of his betrayal and how she finally found peace

🔴Zelensky has urged the UN Security Council to throw out Russia, arguing that its membership gives the Kremlin the right to sow death.

But could Russia be removed from UN Security Council? 👇
⚡️Zelensky has urged the UN Security Council to throw out Russia, arguing that its membership gives the Kremlin the right to sow death
Read @JamesCrisp6 ’s piece in full here👇

❓Is the UN Security Council effective?

It can be, but it isn’t always. 

If a country breaks a UN resolution it can face sanctions, embargoes and military action. 

The UN cannot put these into action itself and must rely on its members to take action
🔴The Council would have to recommend Russia’s removal, which would need to be approved by a two-thirds majority of the 193-state General Assembly

❓Can Russia be expelled from the UN Security Council?

Russia can only be thrown out of the Security Council if Moscow agrees to its own expulsion

❓Does Russia use its veto?

No other  P5  member has wielded its veto so readily as Russia. 

In February, Moscow vetoed a UN Security Council resolution demanding Russia immediately end its attack on Ukraine and withdraw all troops.
🔴This means that Russia is able to block any UN resolution on the war in Ukraine that it does not like. Moscow has repeatedly wielded the veto

❓Why does Zelensky want Russia to be expelled?

President Zelensky challenged the Security Council to expel Russia and so remove its veto, which he said prevented any meaningful action against Vladimir Putin’s regime

❓Who is in the UN Security Council?

The Council has 15 members in total, and five permanent members. The permanent members are the United Kingdom, France, the United States, China and Russia, while other members rotate

❓What is the UN Security Council?

It is the body responsible for international peace and security, recommending the admission of new UN members to the General Assembly and approving any changes to the UN Charter
